comments.commentBody: The donkey is now the owner...

THIS is going to be a great match!!!!
Can't wait! Go USA!!
I am so happy that we are playing the best teams in the world before the WC, as it's the only way to prepare properly!
Just wish Bornstein wasn't on the roster, he is horrible.
Hey Yael - been fun reading this. Great seeing you in Philly. Good luck in the Algarve.
How Beasley and Johnson merit a call-up is a mystery.

..."When you are the first black governor of New York and black elected officials and members of the clergy are gathering to light the path to your exit, you are in deep, deep trouble."

Come on, Bob! Get with it! Psychopaths come in every size, shape and color! And we have more than a few holding high office in both state and federal government! David Paterson does not really count, because he was not elected Governor of New York--it fell to him when Eliot Spitzer was forced to resign. So a competent, very smart, but adulterous Governor is replaced by an incompetent, psychopathic, adulterous Governor! Way to go, New York!!!

Just think what would have happened if John Edwards had been the Democratic nominee for President, and if he had won??? And now, if the Republicans nominate Newt Gingrich, wowzie, there is another salacious story! Politics is full of them! End of story.

Abandoning his campaign is not enough. David Paterson needs to resign. He has severely compromised his office and can not serve effectively.

For too long David Paterson has used his office, whether it be as head of the Senate Minority, Lt. Governor or as Governor, as an employment agency for his unqualified friends, associates, and gal pals – David Johnson, Clemmie Harris, Michael Jones-Bey, Gabrielle Turner, Indira Noel…. This practice needs to stop now.

His staff and all his friends that he has placed in jobs need to be cleaned out as well...GET HIM AND THEM OUT NOW.

This UN-ELECTED GOV needs to go now, before more damage is done and more of the wrong people profit from his office.

The David Johnson episode provides further evidence that David Paterson is just up not up to the task of governing. He does not have what it takes to govern effectively. “The Democratic Conference Organizational and Structural Report” detailing the workings of Paterson’s office while he was Senate Minority leader in the New York State Senate is an objective assessment of this clowns ability to manage or more precisely mismanage.

http://www.politico.com...

This scathing report indicated that Paterson’s Senate Minority office, headed by the supremely incompetent Michael Jones-Bey, was completely dysfunctional. Mr. Jones-Bey, a childhood friend of Paterson, who is now incredulously Director of Division of Minority & Women's Business Development at New York State’s Empire State Development Corporation, was reported to be more interested in partying and boozing up with staff than working.

Wow! You can be a total bozo, ex-felon, or women batterer, but if you a friend or gal pal and work for David Paterson you get promoted and protected for such behavior.

TIME TO GO.

This whole incident is indicative of an age-old pattern -- violent crimes against women are not taken seriously. The man is "entitled" to "straighten out" the woman or "she was asking for it" or it's "a private matter." Just because laws have changed in the past 20 years doesn't mean attitudes have, especially among police.

According to the audio tape of the woman's petition for a restraining order, the judge in the case observed that the woman -- who sounded terribly despondent or fearful on the tape -- had bruises on her arms. Obviously, this woman was physically abused by someone. But the State Police still thought it more important to protect a male aide to the governor than to protect a woman who was afraid for her physical safety. No wonder she didn't show up for her appointed hearing. A call from the governor, no matter how "conciliatory" or "sympathetic" he pretended to be, would set off alarm bells for any woman, especially one who had been "counseled" by State Police about her "options."

Any way you look at it, this was a terrible case of domestic abuse & a worse case of an attempted cover-up of a violent crime against a woman in the presence of her child.

That this particular governor has made the pretense of being a champion of victims of domestic violence is not just ironic. Because violence was involved, Gov. Paterson's hypocrisy exceeds that of the Larry Craigs & David Vitters & John Ensigns.

In his press conference today, Paterson had the audacity to use his wife as a "family values" prop while he asserted he was doing a great job for New Yorkers. It was stomach-churning.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

That's the problem with stereotypes. They are easy to construct and extremely hard to destroy. They are propagated seemingly unknowingly like a virus. Thinking on how to stop stereotypes after they are created is not simple at all. Some interesting thoughts I remember reading about how to deal with stereotypes http://www.pandalous.com...

comments.userDisplayName: Phil in the mountains of Kyushu
comments.commentBody:
I'm going to highlight some of your words here:

"Mr. Johnson was accused of attacking his longtime companion — stripping off most of her clothes, choking her, slamming her against a dresser . . .."

As I read this, my initial shock shifted, and I thought -- assistants to administrators of political power do such violence? And then I thought -- hey, Yoo and Bybee wrote the legal memos which said executives may employ any terror they like -- even if it's expressly disgusting and against the law. And didn't Addington and crew help Cheney organize even worse systems of degradation? And doesn't dear Peace Prize Prez O say he will never object -- that his version of law excludes "litigating the past."

So I don't understand. One man does what he apparently, allegedly did -- and we saints and exceptionalists may high-mindedly blame him, but overlook the massive and continuing worse that we countenance -- and for the magnificently worse reasons that such vulgarities benefit the U.S. corporate elites who can only survive by such and by their minions of Congress persons and other corporate revolving-door corrupted.
ALWAYS strikes me that it's rare to see any 'normal' black families portrayed in movies/tv. either dirt poor, drug addicted or overachievers...
Difficult to consider, but maybe Terry Perry is catering to [white] audiences' stereotypical views of [black] urban-dwellers.  The color he is probably most concerned with is gr$$n.

Somehow I find your inclusion of Tyler Perry's name in the title misleading. Why get personal when you have all those stats. Surely neither Perry nor the cast of "Precious" are responsible for them. And just because you have not seen it in film, white addicts are aplenty too, if you have seen Dr, Phil lately.

These women need help, not for their addictions to be called myths!
You've been on a roll this year Bob.  Another excellent article, right on the money.  Paterson does not deserve to serve out his term if these allegations of his intervention are true.

You're right, of course, & a number of critics agree with you. But for Mo'nique's sake, let's just consider "Precious" a period piece – you know, like Henry James on crack.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

comments.userDisplayName: Prof. Nat Irvin, College of Business
comments.commentBody: ...exceptionally well done Mr. Blow...let it go for sure.

Should we not say yeoperson?

Can MADPROPS possibly be right? And if so, Why?
You wonder sometimes where stereotypes come from!?!

If people didn't realize that the Olympics were all about money, what rock have you been living under? The IOC gets billions from NBC. NBC needs to get its money back from advertisers.

I dislike the system, but we have all been fooled into believing that athletes should compete for free so that the IOC can rake in billions. The athletes are being used, all in the name of patriotism. We need a true, non-profit, to organize a set of fair competitions, not one ruled by commercial considerations.

Getting mad about the Olympics and getting mad about the lack of affordable healthcare (inability of Congress to get anything done on healthcare) aren't mutually exclusive. I don't see why Senator Kohl can't take a moment to ask NBC to justify their existence.

Cut them some slack. And maybe you should note that the drinking age where Marie Philip Poulin comes from in Canada is 18, so even if she hadn't been caught up in celebrating, she might not have considered that the drinking age differed in Vancouver.

I would just point out they skated school figures up until 1992, which counted 20%, then short was 30% and long 50%. In 92, Yamaguchi was co-favorite with Midori Ito, who had that huge triple axel. School figures did in Ito's hopes who came in somewhere about 10th, while Yamaguchi was 2nd, I believe. Since they were using the ordinal system, the true penalty of coming in ~10th was impossible for Ito to overcome.

One result of eliminating school figures is that younger skaters seemed to be advantaged, as skaters like Baiul, LIpinski, and Hughes, all won golds, the year after first competing internationally at Worlds. Before that, the Ladies champions were a bit older, as they required a little more seasoning, as school figures required time to perfect.

NATO troops are fighting in Afghanistan, Iran wants bombs, the economy is still sick, debts are growing, health costs are soaring, 9% are out of work.. and a gaggle of great and happy gals upset people. Team good, you Puritans bad.

I strongly recommend La Cuina de Pilar. Do be scared that they do not have a menu on their website, in fact, that is one of the many intriguing items associated with this restaurant. There menu various every day depending on the freshest (let me emphasize freshest) products available in the markets. There dishes are unique and offer a great taste of Valencia's produce and seafood. If you are planning a trip to Spain make sure to visit this restaurant. There website is: http://www.lacuinadepilar.es/

Martin,

I'll bet it's hard to come up with two common words that, when put together, wouldn't get 100,000 hits on Google. That doesn't mean the usage is correct. Why, even Elke Klijster got a few.

My biggest problem with the Klijster clue was that, since KIMS didn't fit the space, I assumed this was a rebus puzzle.
This is not what it looks like...
